title: La Cenicienta (Cinderella) Font ID
content:
Hi guys:

It's me again, I'm looking forward to ID the font used in this:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150327213019im_/http:/typophile.com/files/LaCenicientaLow_5078.jpg)

Thanks in advance, I'll be around...

Q™ Says: It's all about the fonts!!
author: Qdzign.com.mx

comments.content:
Mmhh...

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150327213019im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Cinderella_6392.jpg)

No one? Any ideas? Anybody? Something? A clue?

I'm still here...

Q™ Says: It's All About The Fonts!

Hi guys:

I'm truly worried... It seems like this font identification thing might look easy, but I know for sure that it is not, I'm writing this 'cause nobody has replied to my post, perhaps this font is a custom job? I'm positive that this is not the case, maybe I have to wait a little longer 'till the right person recognize it and help me with some useful information...

I'll be here forever if I have to... he he he!!

Thanks to all...

Q™ Says: It's All About The Fonts!

Hello:

If it helps, here's another graphic...

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150327213019im_/http:/typophile.com/files/CinderellaBW_4237.jpg)

Q™ Says: It's All About The Fonts!
In some ways it looks as if someone added a stroke to a font to make it faux-bold. I wish I could help more than that.

Hi Tiffany:

It might look like it, but what they actually did is leave the contour that surrounds the original typeface, I'm inserting a closeup so you can see it...

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150327213019im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Cin_3670.jpg)

I'm going mad searching through my Back Up CD's trying to find this font!!

I'm still struggling, I'm still here...

Thanks!!

Q™ Says: It's All About The Fonts!

Hello:

Another sample, just in case...

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150327213019im_/http:/typophile.com/files/CinderellaIII_6427.jpg)

Q™ Says: It's All About The Fonts!

So far the only italic I found with an 'n' like this is [Edwardian](http://web.archive.org/web/20150327213019/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/edwardian/), but if you look at the other letters many of them do not match. I think Disney has used certain typefaces as starting points, but customizes them to suit their readability needs. Perhaps all they did was borrow the idea of the Edwardian n (although the C matches pretty well too).

- Mike Yanega

Mike:

Hey!! Thanks for the info, very useful, I wasn't going for the full fit of the font, just something to start with, and this is an excellent beginning...

Very appreciated information!!

Q™ Says: It's All About The Fonts!
